titlestmt.title: The Song of Los Copy B : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities, the Library of Congress, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a software grant from Inso Corporation and hardware and software grants from Sun Microsystems
titlestmt.funder: Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art, 1997-98

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 65KB; 16 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 135KB to 1000KB
filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive are pleased to announce the publication of seven new electronic editions of Blake's illuminated books. They are: The [First] Book of Urizen Copy G, The Book of Los Copy A, The Book of Ahania Copy A, The Song of Los Copy B, America, a Prophecy Copy A, Europe, a Prophecy Copy E, and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F.
We had announced Urizen Copy G as forthcoming two months ago, but formatting the double-columned text diplomatically in SGML for both Netscape and Internet Explorer proved more taxing and time consuming than anticipated. Such are the joys and tribulations of electronic publishing. Solving the problems there, though, ensured diplomatic transcriptions for Blake's other books with double-columned texts, The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los. Together, these three works are often referred to as Blake's Bible of Hell or, simply, the Urizen books. Urizen, of which there are only seven extant copies, was first produced in 1794, color printed to form Copies A, C, D, E (untraced), F, and J. It was printed again in 1795 to form Copy B, which was produced as part of a set of illuminated books printed on large paper, and then one last time in c. 1818 to form Copy G, which was produced in Blake's late printing and coloring style. The editors are currently working on Copies A, B, C, and F and expect to have them in the Archive by the end of the year. The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los exist in unique copies, with only a few proof impressions extant. They were printed in 1795 and executed in intaglio instead of in relief etching, the technique Blake normally used for his illuminated books. Although their texts are printed in intaglio, their frontispieces are beautifully color printed from the surface of the plates.
With The Song of Los, which consists of two parts entitled "Africa" and "Asia," we complete Blake's other series of illuminated books, sometimes known as the Continental Prophecies, begun in 1793 with America and continued in 1794 with Europe. The copy of The Song of Los included here is one of six extant; all were color printed in the same printing session in 1795.
With fourteen complete copies extant, America is not as rare as these other illuminated books, but Copy A, which was printed and colored in 1795 as part of Blake's large-paper set of books, is, along with Copies K, O, and M, one of only four colored copies—and it was the model for Copy K. Moreover, only it and Copy O have the last four lines on Plate 4, which was masked in the printing of the other copies. The Archive will include Copies M and O (c. 1807 and 1818) later this year.
Only nine copies of Europe are extant, and only two of those, Copies H and O (1795 and 1818), have Plate 3, the Preludium. The Archive will include both of these Copies by the end of the year. Copy E, included here, was lightly color printed on both sides of the paper in 1794 and joins Copy B, color printed more heavily on one side of the paper the same year.
Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F is an exquisitely beautiful copy, heavily color printed (especially its frontispiece) in c. 1794, and never before reproduced. It joins Copies C and J (both 1793), and will be joined later this year by Copies G and P (1795 and 1818).
All of these editions have newly edited texts; all images in the editions were scanned from either 4x5 or 8x10 transparencies, nearly all of which were made specifically for the Archive. Like our other editions, these are all SGML-encoded, fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
The Archive now contains sixteen copies of ten illuminated books. In the coming months, we will be adding copies of All Religions are One, There is No Natural Religion, For the Sexes, Milton, and Jerusalem, along with copies of books already in the Archive but from different printings. Our goal is to have the entire illuminated canon online this year. In addition, work continues on the SGML edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake, which we anticipate releasing sometime this spring.

This work has been revised in order to meet the Archive's more rigorous standards (established summer 2002) for textual transcriptions and illustration descriptions.
Conversion to XML and Blake Archive Description DTD 2004
changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: Andrea LaueConversion: Aziza Technology AssociatesProject Manager: Justin Van KleeckProject Assistants: Christopher N. objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is named as the printer on the title page, but he is also the "publisher."

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 24.3 x 17.5 cm. and 21.5 x 13.5 cm.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching with color printing and hand coloring. The title page and full-plate designs (Objects 1-2, 5, 8) were color printed planographically.
objinfo.printingstyle: Relief with color printing. The title page and full-plate designs (Objects 1-2, 5, 8) were color printed planographically.
objinfo.inkcolor: gray-brown (Objects 2-4, 6, and 7)Objects 1, 5, and 8 may not contain any underlying ink beneath the thick color printing. The gray-brown color of the text on Object 2 may be color-printing medium rather than ink.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Objects 2-8 numbered 2, 4, 6-8, 10, 11 top right.The pen and ink numbers are very probably not by Blake but were added by another hand when *The Song of Los* Copy B was interleaved and bound with three other prints by Blake.
objinfo.binding: loose in portfolioOnce bound with several other works by Blake, but disbound and separated by 1904.

provenance.name: Library of Congress
provenance.date: Acquired by Lessing J. Rosenwald in 1929; given to the Library of Congress in 1945.
provenance.note: Probably acquired by the Earl of Beaconsfield between 1856 and 1862; sold anonymously, Hodgson's, 14 Jan. 1904, lot 224 (£144 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); acquired by William A. White; sold from White's estate in 1927 through the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach to Lessing J.Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1945.

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see from behind a figure, probably male, kneeling and bowing over an altar. He may be praying. His feet are prominently displayed beneath the hem of a garment that extends only to his waist. The altar, perhaps made of stone, has a top that could be an open book, seen only along its lower edge. The mottled ground on which the figure kneels may be covered with grass or lichens. Above the figure is a large disc (probably meant to be a globe) covered with dark patches suggestive of unreadable inscriptions, hieroglyphics, or simply chaos. This may be a dark or occluded sun. Four beams of dark radiance extend from this sun, diagonally in relation to the sides of the design. The area surrounding the globe is probably the void of space. The dark area beneath the globe, rising from the left to the right margin and above the figure's head, may be a distant mountain. The figure might be either Urizen (note the white hair) or a priest who represents false religion.

component.illusobjdesc: We see from behind a figure, probably male, kneeling and bowing over an altar. He may be praying. His feet are prominently displayed beneath the hem of a garment that extends only to his waist. The figure might be either Urizen (note the white hair) or a priest who represents false religion.
The figure kneels before and bows over what is probably a stone altar. The top of the altar may be an open book, seen only along its lower edge.

Above the figure is a large disc (probably meant to be a globe) covered with dark patches suggestive of unreadable inscriptions, hieroglyphics, or simply chaos. This may be a dark or occluded sun. Four beams of dark radiance extend from this sun, diagonally in relation to the sides of the design. The area around the globe is probably just the void of space. The dark area beneath the globe, rising from the left to the right margin and above the figure's head, may be a distant mountain.
The mottled ground on which the figure kneels may be covered with grass or lichens.

desc.objtitle: THE SONG of LOS, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The title page is treated as a full-page design, with the area bearing the title words (lines 2-4) treated as the sky. At the lower margin, an old bearded man lies supine on the ground. His gown covers all but his left hand, which rests on a skull, and his face. He faces and looks up, with his legs extended to the left. This figure has been variously identified as Urizen, Moses, Adam, and Noah--see "And Noah as white as snow / On the mountains of Ararat" (Plate 7, lines 23-24). The skull may be Adam's--see "For Adam, a mouldering skeleton / Lay bleach'd on the garden of Eden" (Plate 7, lines 21-22). The background behind and above the figure may be hills (covered with indeterminate vegetation) closest to the figure, and either more distant hills or waves of the sea in the far background. The spiky forms, colored red, could be flames. Above, in the sky, are four birds in flight with extended wings: a bird right of "The" in the title (line 2), and three birds (one large, color printed in red) above and to the left of the first letter of "LOS" (line 4) in the title.

component.illusobjdesc: An old bearded man with long hair lies supine on the ground. His gown covers all but his left hand, which rests on a skull, and his face. He faces and looks up, with his legs extended to the left. This figure has been variously identified as Urizen, Moses, Adam, and Noah--see "And Noah as white as snow / On the mountains of Ararat" (Plate 7, lines 23-24).
The old man rests his left hand on a human skull, perhaps the skull of Adam--see "For Adam, a mouldering skeleton / Lay bleach'd on the garden of Eden" (Plate 7, lines 21-22).
The background behind and above the figure may be composed of hills, closest to him, and either hills or waves of the sea in the distance. The spiky forms, colored red, could be flames.
The hill directly behind and above the figure may be covered with some sort of vegetation.
The area containing the text of the title is treated as though it were the sky.
The faint outline of a bird in flight, with extended wings, can be seen to the right of the first word in the title ("The," line 2).
Three birds fly with extended wings below the "S" of "SONG" (line 3) in the title inscription.

lg.l: THE
SONG of
LOS
LambethPrinted by W Blake1795

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake is intertwined through the letters of the heading ("AFRICA," line 2). The snake's head points down and its mouth is open; its forked tongue hangs down. The reptilian theme is continued by a small lizard, apparently climbing the first diagonal of the first "A" in the heading. Many vines, some with loops and spirals (far left), and a few leaves also play about and are intertwined with the heading. Several flying insects, perhaps moths or butterflies, are also pictured, particularly below the first "A" and the "F" of the heading and just below and left of the final "A." A bird with extended wings flies below the snake's tail where it twists below the final "A" of the heading. Below, with five lines of text intervening, is the lower half of what is probably a unified composition, particularly given the marginal vegetation linking them. On the left is a nude young male, probably a shepherd boy, lying on the ground in a contracted posture and probably sleeping. The downward-directed mouth of the serpent above may be threatening him. The male's legs are drawn up and his head, with curly hair, rests face down on his left arm. To the right is at least one sheep, also lying on the ground with its face on the left. Further to the right may be more sheep plus some vegetation. Above this area, and just below the final word of line 4, is a flying insect with bat-like wings. A caterpillar crawls on a vine beneath this bat-winged insect.

component.illusobjdesc: A snake is intertwined through the letters of the heading ("AFRICA," line 2). The snake's mouth is open; its forked tongue hangs down. The snake may be threatening the sleeping youth below his downward-pointing head.
A small lizard climbs the first diagonal of the first "A" in the heading ("AFRICA," line 2).
At least one sheep lies on the ground right of the sleeping youth. The sheep's head is on the left; it may be asleep. The densely color-printed area to the right may include other sheep.
Several winged insects, perhaps butterflies or moths, hover below the first "A" and the "F" of the heading ("AFRICA," line 2).
Several winged insects, perhaps butterflies or moths, hover between the "C" and final "A" of the heading ("AFRICA," line 2).
A small bird flies on extended wings below the snake's tail where it curls beneath the final "A" of the heading (line 2).
A bat-winged insect, perhaps a moth or butterfly, hovers below and to the right of the final word in line 4.
A caterpillar climbs a vine right of the sheep and below the bat-winged insect.

A nude male youth, perhaps a child, lies on the ground. His legs are drawn up and his face rests on his left arm. We see only the top of his head and his curly hair. Given his proximity to the sheep to the right, this may be a sleeping shepherd.
Many vines, some with leaves, are intertwined with the heading ("AFRICA," line 2). At least one, far left, includes loops and a spiral.

Green color printing left of the sleeping figure and extending along most of the left margin of the plate probably represents vegetation. One vine or bare branch extends from this marginal coloring to the indented beginning of line 5 of the text.
The dense color printing right of the sheep may represent vegetation.

lg.l: AFRICA

component.illusobjdesc: The text of the heading is fully integrated into the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The plate contains a good deal of interlinear decoration. Several vines with leaves and loops extend between lines 11 and 13 of the text. This area also includes two flying birds, wings extended, below "children of Los" in line 11. Other vines follow line 15 (very poorly printed) and fill the space between lines 21 and 22. Green color printing, probably representing vegetation, extends along the right margin from line 17 to the bottom of the plate. A reptile of some sort, possibly a snake or lizard, emerges from this vegetation and faces left, holding its mouth open.

component.illusobjdesc: Two birds fly, with wings extended, below "children of Los" in line 11 of the text.

Several vines extend horizontally between lines 11 and 13 of the text. The vine on the left forms loops; the center vine bears at least one ivy-like leaf. This vine merges with at least one other near the right margin. Two of its tendrils form loops suggestive of (if not quite forming) spirals.
Fragments of a poorly-printed vine, perhaps with ivy-like leaves, extends horizontally from the end of line 15 of the text toward the right margin.
A snake-like vine twists horizontally between lines 21 and 22 of the text.
A reptile of some sort, possibly a snake or lizard, emerges from the vegetation right of lines 17-19 and faces left, holding its mouth open.

Dark green and brown color printing along the right margin, extending from line 17 to the bottom of the plate, suggests vegetation. These patches extend in roughly triangular form into the interstices between lines of text. The extension between lines 28 and 29 reaches to the left margin and looks like a vine.

lg.l: I will sing you a song of Los, the Eternal Prophet:
He sung it to four harps at the tables of Eternity.
In heart-formed Africa.
Urizen faded! Ariston shudderd!
And thus the Song began
Adam stood in the garden of Eden:
And Noah on the mountains of Ararat:
They saw Urizen give his Laws to the Nations
By the hands of the children of Los.
African
Adam shudderd! Noah faded! black grew the sunny
When Rintrah gave Abstract Philosophy to Brama in the East.
(Night spoke to the Cloud!
Lo these Human form'd spirits in smiling hipocrisy. War
Against one another; so let them War on; slaves to the
eternal Elements)
Noah shrunk beneath the waters:
Abram fled in fires from Chaldea;
Moses beheld upon Mount Sinai forms of dark delusion;
To Trismegistus. Palamabron gave an abstract Law;
To Pythagoras Socrates & Plato.
Times rolled on o'er all the sons of Har, time after time
Orc on Mount Atlas howld. chain'd down with the Chain of Jealousy
Then Oothoon hoverd over Judah & Jerusalem
And Jesus heard her voice (a man of sorrows) he recievd
A Gospel from wretched Theotormon.
The human race began to wither. for the healthy built
Secluded places, fearing the joys of Love
And the disease'd only propagated;
So Antamon call'd up Leutha from her valleys of delight:
And to Mahomet a loose Bible gave.
But in the North, to Odin, Sotha gave a Code of War.
Because of Diralada thinking to reclaim his joy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The plate is treated as a full-page design, with the text areas representing clouds in the sky. On the earth below the text, an embracing couple runs to the right. These are probably Har and Heva, who "fled" from the "War & Lust" of "their brethren" (lines 6-7). They face forward, but may be looking back to the left. Both faces express fear or horror. The male is nude and has his mouth slightly open, as though speaking or uttering a cry. The female wears a skirt but would appear to be undraped above the waist. The female's hair is long, the man's curly. They appear to be fleeing from some unrepresented presence on the left. The man's left arm holds the woman's waist; his right arm is not visible. The woman's left arm is wrapped around the man's head. Her right arm is extended at 135 degrees, with the palm facing to the left as though fending off a pursuer. The ground on which they run may be covered with low vegetation. A hill rises on the right; left of the figures is a dark sky streaked with red, perhaps indicating a sunrise or sunset. A mountain, perhaps partly covered with snow, rises in the right background. Just above, in the cloud or text panel into which the woman's right arm extends, are two birds with wings extended. The entire scene is apocalyptic. Above, on the upper cloud or text panel, is a nude human figure, probably male, hovering in the air. We see him from behind, with one leg drawn up and the other extended. He faces to the left, with his arms extended horizontally. His large, bat-like wings extend below his arms.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male embraces a woman and runs to the right. He faces forward, but may be looking back to the left at some unrepresented presence from which he is fleeing. His hair is curly. His left arm holds the woman around the waist; his right arm is not visible. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying. His face expresses fear or terror. He is probably Har, who "fled" with Heva from the "War & Lust" of "their brethren" (lines 6-7).

A woman, embracing and embraced by a man, runs with an exaggerated stride to the right. She has long hair and a skirt, but would appear to be nude above the waist. She faces forward, but perhaps looks back to the left at some unrepresented presence from which she is fleeing. Her left arm is wrapped around the man's head; her right arm is extended at 135 degrees with the palm facing to the left, as though she were fending off some pursuer. Her mouth is open; she may be speaking or crying out. Her face suggests fear or terror, and her mouth is partly open. She is probably Heva, who with Har "fled" from the "War & Lust" of "their brethren" (lines 6-7).

A figure, nude and probably male, hovers in the upper cloud or text panel. We see him from behind, with one leg extended and one drawn up. He faces to the left; his arms are raised horizontally. His large, bat-like wings extend just below his arms.
Two birds with extended wings fly to the left of the woman's extended right arm.
The ground over which the embracing couple runs may be covered with low vegetation, such as grass.
A hill or mound of vegetation rises in the background behind the embracing couple. Farther back there may be a low mountain range.
A mountain, perhaps partly covered with snow, rises in the right background.
Red streaks in the sky left of the embracing couple suggest a sunrise or sunset.
Given their shape, the text panels would seem to function as clouds within the pictorial image.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The left margin of the text is decorated with several vines. One extends vertically from line 13 to line 2. Horizontal vines extend from the beginning of line 4 to the left margin and between lines 5 and 6. Vines with loops appear in the left margin at lines 19 to 21, and at the start of line 22. A bird soars on extended wings above "Rousseau" in line 19. What might be another bird appears in the top left corner of the plate. Two insects, possibly moths, appear left of lines 8 and 9, beneath a faintly printed vine with a loop.

component.illusobjdesc: A bird soars on extended wings above "Rousseau" in line 19 of the text.
What might be a bird flying on extended wings appears at the top left corner of the plate.
Two insects, possibly moths, hover in the margin left of lines 8 and 9.
A curving line that may represent a vine extends vertically in the right margin of the text from lines 13 to 2. To the left of this vine is another, more faintly printed vine with at least one loop.
A vine, perhaps with small leaves, extends horizontally between the left margin and the beginning of line 4.
A vine extends from the first letter in line 6 of the text and continues horizontally between lines 5 and 6.
A vine grows from the first letter in line 14 of the text.
A horizontal line between lines 18 and 19 of the text may represent a vine or low hills--or possibly a break in the clouds.
A vine extends from the "d" of "clouds" in line 18.
A vine with many loops appears in the margin left of lines 19 to 21 of the text.
A vine with two branches and several loops extends downward left of the first word in line 22. Below it are two very faintly printed leaves.

lg.l: These were the Churches: Hospitals: Castles; Palaces;
Like nets & gins & traps to catch the joys of Eternity
And all the rest a desart;
Till like a dream Eternity was obliterated & erased.
Since that dread day when Har and Heva fled.
Because their brethren & sisters liv'd in War & Lust;
And as they fled they shrunk
Into two narrow doleful forms:
Creeping in reptile flesh upon
The bosom of the ground:
And all the vast of Nature shrunk
Before their shrunken eyes.
Thus the terrible race of Los & Enitharmon gave
Laws & Religions to the sons of Har binding them more
And more to Earth: closing and restraining:
Till a Philosophy of Five Senses was complete
Urizen wept & gave it into the hands of Newton & Locke
Clouds roll heavy upon the Alps round Rousseau & Voltaire:
And on the mountains of Lebanon round the deceased Gods
Of Asia; & on the desarts of Africa round the Fallen Angels
The Guardian Prince of Albion burns in his nightly tent

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures rest on large lilies. The ground from which the lily plant grows is not clearly represented, but there may be a river behind its stems. If we assume that this is a plant of normal size, then the human figures are diminutive, perhaps fairies. The female, wearing a gown that seemingly does not cover her left shoulder, lies on one blossom with eyes closed; she may be asleep. Her head rests on her right arm and hand. Her hair is long. The male wears a long gown and a separate cloak. He is crowned, and thus probably a king; by association, the woman may be a queen. His eyes are open and he faces forward. He has long hair and a beard. He is more seated than lying on his blossom, with his upper body propped up with his right arm. He holds a scepter in his left hand. The night sky in the distance contains a few indications of stars. The design is based loosely on a monochrome wash drawing, now usually attributed to Blake's brother Robert, in Blake's Notebook, page 5. There is also a separate water color of the design by William Blake (private collection). The two figures have traditionally been identified as Oberon and Titania, although the relevance of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream to *The Song of Los* is not immediately apparent. Other critics have identified the figures as Har and Heva, as on Plate 4. Perhaps, given the cosmic scale of Plate 8, this plate represents the microscopic world of the Blakean imagination.

component.illusobjdesc: A male figure, wearing a gown and a separate cloak, sits on a lily. If the flower determines the scale, then this diminutive male may be a fairy. He is crowned and holds a scepter in his left hand; he may be a king. He props up his upper body with his right arm; his right leg is drawn up and his left leg dangles from the edge of the flower. He faces forward and has long hair and a beard. He has been identified by modern critics as either Har (see Plate 4) or Oberon from Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream.

A female wearing a gown lies on a lily. Her left shoulder is bare. Her head and long hair rest on her right arm. Her eyes are closed and she may be sleeping. If the scale of the design is determined by the flower, then this diminutive female may be a fairy. Given her association with the crowned male to the right, she may be a queen. She has been identified by modern critics as either Heva (see Plate 4) or Titania from Shakespeare's *A Midsummer Night's Dream*.
A lily plant, with three blossoms (two fully open), and its stems and leaves dominate the image.
A gray horizontal section of color printing may represent a river behind the lily plant.
The night sky bears a few white spots that may indicate stars.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate would seem to be treated as a single, interrelated pictorial image. Several figures, not very clearly defined, disport among the letters of the heading ("ASIA," line 2). A seated figure, with knees drawn up, appears just left of the first letter. This figure, of uncertain gender, has her or his head lowered. Within the upper loop of the second letter, a figure clutches his head and falls head first. Two embracing figures, poorly defined but probably a male and female, stride to the left just left of the lower part of the letter "I." An ill-defined cluster of lines may be a seated figure at the lower parts of the final "A." The sky behind the heading contains clouds and is streaked with red, perhaps representing a sunrise or sunset. Below, we see a great tree arching over from left to right. In a cave-like niche below the tree are two figures, a nude male holding a gowned woman. He squats or sits on the ground, apparently with his head lowered since we see only the curly hair on the top of his head. The female's head and left arm fall downward; she may be dead. The dark green coloring to the left of the man and woman may be vegetation. Undifferentiated vegetation continues down both margins of the text; some vine-like shapes intrude between lines of text and fill areas on the right of the text. A nude figure, probably male, sits or kneels in an extremely contracted posture in the lower right corner of the plate. His left leg is drawn up to his left shoulder. His head is turned to the left (his face is not pictured); he clutches his lowered head with both hands. He (or, perhaps, she) may have long hair.

component.illusobjdesc: A small figure, with legs drawn up to the chest, sits to the left of the first "A" in the heading ("ASIA," line 2). The figure's head may be lowered to his or her knees.
A nude figure, probably male, falls head first at the top of the letter "S" of the heading (line 2). He clutches his head with both hands. His legs are spread apart, with one leg bent at the knee.

Two figures, probably a male and female, stride to the left just left of the lower part of the letter "I" in the heading (line 2). Both seem to wear gowns and are probably embracing. The lower portions of their gowns trail to the right; a long scarf floats to the right behind one of the figures.
A cluster of lines between the two diagonals of the final "A" of the heading (line 2) may represent a gowned and seated figure.

A nude male sits or kneels on one leg (just above line 3) and holds a dead or dying female. His right leg is drawn up just to the left of his right shoulder. His face is not shown; we see only his curly hair.
A gowned female (just above line 3) is held by a nude man. Her head, long hair, and left arm descend limply downward; she may be dead. Her legs and the drapery from her gown are bent beneath her.

A nude figure, probably male, sits or kneels in an extremely contracted posture in the lower right corner of the plate. His left leg is drawn up to his left shoulder. His head is turned to the left (his face is not pictured); he clutches his lowered head with both hands. He (or, perhaps, she) may have long hair.
A large tree arches over and forms a cave for the man holding the (dead?) woman.
The dark green coloring to the left of the man and woman may be vegetation.
A good deal of undifferentiated vegetation decorates both margins of the text. Some of this vegetation intrudes, in the form of vines, between lines of text.
The sky behind and above the heading contains clouds. The red and pink coloring suggests a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: ASIA

component.illusobjdesc: The heading is fully integrated into the pictorial image.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A good deal of undifferentiated vegetation decorates both margins of the text. Some of this vegetation intrudes in the form of vines or branches between lines 7-8, 15-16, 19-20, and 23-24.

component.illusobjdesc: A good deal of undifferentiated vegetation decorates both margins of the text. Some of this vegetation intrudes, in the form of vines or branches, between lines 7-8, 15-16, 19-20, and 23-24. The vine between 7-8 grows into a leafy branch that extends downward into the right margin. An additional vine descends right of "laborious" in line 17, merges with the vegetation beneath the kneeling figure, and attaches to the final letter of "path" in line 24. A vine with two loops also grows from the first letter of line 24.
A vine with several loops extends from the first letter of line 1.
A vine with several loops extends from the first letter of line 10 and connects to the first letter of "King" later in the same line.

lg.l: The Kings of Asia heard
The howl rise up from Europe!
And each ran out from his Web;
From his ancient woven Den;
For the darkness of Asia was startled
At the thick-flaming, thought-creating fires of Orc.
And the Kings of Asia stood
And cried in bitterness of soul.
Shall not the King call for Famine from the heath?
Nor the Priest, for Pestilence from the fen?
To restrain! to dismay! to thin!
The inhabitants of mountain and plain;
In the day of full-feeding prosperity;
And the night of delicious songs.
Shall not the Councellor throw his curb
Of Poverty on the laborious?
To fix the price of labour;
To invent allegoric riches:
And the privy admonishers of men
Call for fires in the City
For heaps of smoking ruins,
In the night of prosperity & wantonness
To turn man from his path,
To restrain the child from the womb,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although it contains considerable text, the plate is treated pictorially as a full-page design. Upper right, a nude male falls head first in front of clouds. His legs are bent at the knee, so that his lower legs are not shown, and his arms are similarly bent at the elbows. His posture is contracted, with his head bent back. Both margins of the text are filled with undifferentiated masses of vegetation, some of which intrude between lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male falls head first in front of clouds. His legs are bent at the knee, so that his lower legs are not shown, and his arms are similarly bent at the elbows. His posture is contracted, with his head bent back. He may be bound.
The right-hand margin of the top half of the plate resembles a dark sky, and the upper text panels seem to function as clouds.
Large masses of undifferentiated vegetation, perhaps including branches and leaves, decorate both margins of the text. Some of this vegetation intrudes between lines of text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "y" in "may" and "y" in "obey" (line 3) extend horizontally between lines 3 and 4 of the text. Other letters of the text have similar vine-like extensions, such as the "p" in "weeping" (line 17), the "d" in "clouds" (line 20), which includes a loop, and the "d" in "Adam" (line 21). An independent vine with multiple loops extends horizontally between lines 9 and 10 of the text. The horizontal forms between lines 34 and 35 may also represent vines.

component.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "y" in "may" and "y" in "obey" (line 3) extend horizontally between lines 3 and 4 of the text. Other letters of the text have similar vine-like extensions, such as the "p" in "weeping" (line 17). An independent vine with multiple loops extends horizontally between lines 9 and 10 of the text. The horizontal forms between lines 35 and 36 may also represent vines.
The horizontal forms between lines 35 and 36 of the text may represent vines.
The right-hand margin of the top half of the plate resembles a dark sky, and the upper text panels seem to function as clouds.

lg.l: To cut off the bread from the city,
That the remnant may learn to obey.
That the pride of the heart may fail;
That the lust of the eyes may be quench'd:
That the delicate ear in its infancy
May be dull'd; and the nostrils clos'd up:
To teach mortal worms the path
That leads from the gates of the Grave.
Urizen heard them cry;
And his shudd'ring waving wings
Went enormous above the red flames
Drawing clouds of despair thro' the heavens
Of Europe as he went:
And his Books of brass iron & gold
Melted over the land as he flew,
Heavy-waving, howling, weeping.
And he stood over Judea;
And stay'd in his ancient place:
And stretch'd his clouds over Jerusalem;
For Adam, a mouldering skeleton
Lay bleach'd on the garden of Eden;
And Noah as white as snow
On the mountains of Ararat.
Then the thunders of Urizen bellow'd aloud
From his woven darkness above.
Orc raging in European darkness
Arose like a pillar of fire above the Alps
Like a serpent of fiery flame!
The sullen Earth
Shrunk!
Forth from the dead dust rattling bones to bones
Join: shaking convuls'd the shivring clay breathes
And all flesh naked stands; Fathers and Friends;
Mothers & Infants; Kings & Warriors;
The Grave shrieks with delight, & shakes
Her hollow womb, & clasps the solid stem;
Her bosom swells with wild desire;
And milk & blood & glandous wine
In rivers rush & shout & dance,
On mountain, dale and plain.
The SONG of LOS is Ended.
Urizen Wept.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits or kneels, with legs spread apart, on what may be clouds or partly formed cosmic globes. He faces forward, but looks down at the darkened globe of an occluded sun or star. He holds, with both hands, a large hammer. His hair is curly or flame-like; his expression is serious, perhaps even melancholy. The dark sun or star below him has, around the lower half of its circumference, spiky beams of light. Right and left of this man are at least two other suns or stars, also radiating beams of light. Beyond is the void of space. The figure is almost certainly Los, in his character as the blacksmith-like creator of the temporal universe.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits or kneels, with legs spread apart, on what may be clouds or partly formed cosmic globes. He faces forward, but looks down at the darkened globe of an occluded sun or star. He hold, with both hands, a large hammer. His left arm is bent under his head, his right arm is bent upward with his right hand resting on top of the handle of the hammer. His hair is curly or flame-like; his expression is serious, perhaps even melancholy. This figure is almost certainly Los, in his character as the blacksmith-like creator of the temporal universe.
The figure may be sitting on either clouds or partly formed cosmic globes.
The man looks down upon a dark or occluded sun or star. Spiky beams of light surround the lower half of its circumference. The dark, horizontal forms in front of the globe suggest clouds.
At least two suns or stars hover right and left of the figure. Spiky beams of light emanate from both.
